DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Italy COVID-19 total cases rose to 9172 from 7375 and the death toll rose to 463 from 366, according to an official. Italian PM Conte announced they are adopting tougher measures to tackle coronavirus and that there will no longer be a red zone but instead the whole country will be under same condition in which movement will be restricted all over Italy. Furthermore, Conte said all public gatherings are to be banned, while the closure of schools and universities all over the country is extended to April 3rd. (Newswires)

US CDC said 472 total confirmed and presumptive cases, including repatriated cases and the death toll rose to 19. (Newswires)

IMF Chief Economist said governments need "substantial" targeted fiscal, monetary and financial market measures to combat drag from coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

BoJ purchased JPY 101.4bln of ETF's today, which is the 3rd time it conducted ETF purchases this month. (Newswires)

Japan are to boost special financing for small and mid-sized firms to JPY 1.6trl which will be announced on Tuesday, according to a government document. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reiterated UK remains in contain phase but added that scientists think containment extremely unlikely to work on its own and we are making extensive preparation for a move to the delay phase. There were also separate reports that UK PM Johnson was urged to unleash an “aggressive” battle against coronavirus now to stop the outbreak spiralling within weeks. (Newswires/Evening Standard)

UK PM Johnson said that the Bank of England has made it clear that they will take all necessary steps to protect financial and monetary stability and the government has also said it will take further action as needed on coronavirus. (Newswires)

UK expects to table a number of legal texts, including a draft FTA” before the next round of talks next week, according to BBC's Fleming. (Twitter)

UK House of Commons Commission decided against closing Parliament over coronavirus fears and sources said they’ll be guided by Cobra meetings, according to FT's Payne. (Twitter)

EZ Finance Ministers raised possibility with banks supervisors of giving firms struggling with virus impact more time that the usual 90 days before their debt is classified as non-performing loans. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said companies hit by COVID-19 will get the help they need, while he added the government will propose liquidity measures this week and EU Summit will discuss impact on March 26th. (Newswires)

Italy is reportedly planning to increase its 2020 budget deficit above 2.5% of GDP (Prev. 2.2%) to help against the coronavirus, according to a government source. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES 

IEA Monthly Report cut 2020 world oil demand forecasts by almost 1mln BPD, due to the coronavirus and envisage the first contraction since 2009. (Newswires)

US DOE delayed the release of its monthly Short Term Energy Outlook by one day to Wednesday to incorporate the recent global oil market events. (Newswires)

Russia's Energy Minister Novak said Russian oil will remain competitive and keep its market share no matter what the projected price of oil is, according to Interfax. (Twitter)

Russia's Rosneft is poised to increase production from April while are also said to be prepared for any oil price scenarios. (Newswires)

It's still too early to "throw in the towel" on an OPEC-Russia alliance, according to a delegate cited by S&P Global Platts. (Twitter)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US official said Trump administration will soon issue an advisory warning anyone holding Iranian oil in violation of US sanctions and will soon also issue maritime advisory to target ships that turn off transponders to avoid sanctions. (Newswires)

Libyan Eastern Commander Haftar is committed to signing a ceasefire deal with French President Macron, according to Elysee. (Newswires)

 

US 

US Senate Finance Committee’s Grassley is mulling targeted tax relief as a result of COVID-19, according to a spokesperson. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

On the back of the crude price obliteration after Saudi began an oil price war and following the OPEC breakdown, COVID-19 and credit concerns, stocks gapped aggressively lower on the Sunday futures open. US futures hit the level 1 (-5%) limit down, banning any transaction below that until the cash open, where within a few minutes of reopening, hit their level 2 (7%) limit down, banning all trade for fifteen minutes, then reopened and soon bounced off their lows, albeit still deeply in the red. Stocks over in Europe had it even harder, Euro Stoxx 50 closed lower by over 8%, with the FTSE MIB down over 11% - futures extended loses. Energy and Financials continued to drag the indices lower as the survivability of shale names, particularly their credit requirements, were further put into question by investors – the Treasury curve bull-flattening to bring all yields beneath 1% was reflective of falling energy prices as well as self-reinforcing to weakness in banks. Participants are also increasingly expecting global fiscal action in face of the virus, where G7 governments have asserted their readiness to support their economies as need be, although nothing concrete has yet been announced in the UK, US and Germany, any shortfall in the eyes of investors will likely deepen the market damage. The Energy sector (XLE, XOP, FANG, APA) was generally offered heavily amid the obliteration of oil prices – although names exposed highly to nat gas fared better (COG, EQT) as the expected decline in drilling activity will be bullish for gas. Continued yield declines, risk aversion and credit concerns, particularly in the energy sector, weighed on financials (XLF, BKX), particularly regional banks (KRE), and even further those with acute loan exposure to US shale oil (BKOF, CMA, CADE). Cruise liners (CCL, RCL, NCLH) found no selling reprieve as US imposed stricter restrictions on trips. Twitter (TWTR) was one of the handful of names in the green after it announced a USD 2bln share repurchase programme while it reached a deal with Silver Lake and Elliott management, who will both get a seat on the board and funding for the share repurchase programme; there was no mention of the removal of CEO Dorsey. Tesla (TSLA) was hit hard by wider risk aversion, despite positive comments from a top shareholder doing the rounds. Apple (AAPL) moved lower with the market alongside reports of a sharp Y/Y decline in its February iPhone sales in China. Aon (AON) were hit after it agreed to purchase Willis Towers Watson (WLTW) for USD 30bln, creating an USD 80bln entity. SPX -7.61% at 2746, NDX -6.83% at 7948, DJI -7.79% at 23,849.

The chunky bid extended on Monday amid the risk aversion and oil price collapse. The curve exhibited further bull flattening alongside weaker inflation expectations and corporate credit concerns as oil prices tumbled further towards their all-time lows, equities were also hit strongly. In the overnight session the 30-year bond was bid as much as six points, with desks noting nobody on the other side of the trade. The rally saw all yields move beneath the 1% figure for the first time in history, and participants now move to the question of when the Fed will cut again rather than if. By settlement, 2-year yield had fallen 21bps while the 30-year had fallen by 38bps to 0.840%, but above its lows of 0.702%. US T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point 8 ticks higher at 139.09+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 9th MARCH 2020: Stocks & oil crushed as Saudi & Russia ram heads
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Crude down, Dollar down.
  • REAR VIEW: Saudi & Russia pricing war, COVID-19 continues to rise outside of China, NY Fed increases Repo operation size
  • COMING UP: Data: China CPI & M2 money supply, EU GDP revisions. Speakers & Events: Norges Bank Regional Network Report, Riksbank’s Ingves & Breman, RBA’s Debelle and RBNZ Governor Orr. Supply: 30bln in 3-year notes from US, 5-year JGB auction, 2030 Gilt auction.

* MARKET WRAP: On the back of the crude price obliteration after the OPEC breakdown, COVID-19 and credit concerns, stocks gapped aggressively lower on the Sunday futures open. US futures hit the level 1 (-5%) limit down, banning any transaction below that until the cash open, where within a few minutes of reopening, hit their level 2 (7%) limit down, banning all trade for fifteen minutes, then reopened and soon bounced off their lows, albeit still deeply in the red. Stocks over in Europe had it even harder, Euro Stoxx 50 closed lower by over 8%, with the FTSE MIB down over 11% - futures extended loses. Energy and Financials continued to drag the indices lower as the survivability of shale names, particularly their credit requirements, were further put into question by investors – the Treasury curve bull-flattening to bring all yields beneath 1% was reflective of falling energy prices as well as self-reinforcing to weakness in banks. Participants are also increasingly expecting global fiscal action in face of the virus, where G7 governments have asserted their readiness to support their economies as need be, although nothing concrete has yet been announced in the UK, US and Germany, any shortfall in the eyes of investors will likely deepen the market damage.

* WTI (J0) SETTLED USD LOWER AT USD /BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD LOWER AT USD /BBL: Energy markets exhibited their largest price declines since the Iraq Gulf war amid the OPEC breakdown. Sources over the weekend noted that Saudi Arabia will be boosting its output to above 10mln BPD from this month’s 9.7mln BPD as a response to the collapse of its OPEC+ alliance with Russia. Saudi is also said to have told market participants that it could raise output to as much as 12mln BPD, although sources stated that the initial increase is likely to total between 10-11mln BPD in April, with the final figure contingent on refiners’ response to price cuts. Furthermore, the Kingdom slashed its official pricing for crude, with oil giant Aramco cutting its Asia prices for Arab Light crude and Medium crude by USD 6/bbl each, to discounts of USD 3.10/bbl and USD 4.05/bbl below the Middle East benchmark respectively. In a challenge to Russia, the company made the largest cut to northwest Europe of some USD 8/bbl in most grades – Russia sells a bulk of its Urals crude in the same region. Arab Light sales to Europe will be at a USD 10.25/bbl discount to Brent – levels not seen since at least May 2002. As a result of the anticipated rising production and slash in OSPs – expected to flood the market with barrels – WTI and Brent futures sank 27% and 30% respectively, with the former paused for a few minutes following its aggressive >7% move. WTI Apr’20 briefly slipped below USD 28/bbl vs. Friday’s USD 41.50/bbl close, while Brent May 20 dipping south of USD 32/bbl vs. Friday’s USD 45.50/close – with the spread also narrowing to ~USD 3.80/bbl vs. ~4/bbl on Friday. The Kingdom hopes the slump in oil prices and the expected diminishing in Russia’s market shares will prompt Moscow back to the negotiating table and force its hand to cut output. Desks note that although this may prove effective in the short-term, it is in less certain what the longer-term impact will be. In the meantime, investors are now cautious on US shale producers, as concerns grow over their ability to continue producing at such low prices and their ability to refinance their debt obligations, especially given recent widening of credit spreads.

* COVID-19: Cases continued to rise outside China, with WHO’s Tedros stating the threat of a pandemic has become very real although “it can still be controlled”. The economic impact continues to seep into the economy while further actions are being taken to help soften the blow. Japan’s MOF’s Takeuchi stated they will respond to excess volatility as appropriate and will pay closer attention to market moves with a sense of urgency. Meanwhile the BoJ purchased JPY 101.4bln worth of ETF’s, the third time this month. Elsewhere multiple reports have suggested the US are discussing a number of options to support the economy which includes, paid sick leave, cashflow injection for small businesses and a tax deferral on specific industries, such as hospitality and travel; a meeting on the matter is expected this afternoon. However, CNBC reported virus ideas were “kicked around” over the weekend but there is nothing on paper and it is still a long way off. In the UK, PM Johnson reiterated the government and Bank of England will take all steps necessary on the coronavirus, while noting the UK remains in the contain phase but has accepted the virus will spready in a significant way. In Europe, German Chancellor Merkel’s government loosened rules for short-term work compensation, making it easier for companies impacted by the coronavirus to apply for aid; government is set to invest a further EUR 12.1bln per annum between 2021 and 2024. Italy's Deputy Economy Minister stated the government and Bank of Italy are looking into a guarantee scheme, to support banks offering moratorium to households and companies following the virus outbreak and is reportedly considering extending tax moratorium as well. Meanwhile, French Finance Minister Le Maire stated the ECB has room for manoeuvre and European Finance Ministers need to come to an economic stimulus plan for the coronavirus, which needs to contain both budgetary and fiscal measures. Also, EZ Finance Ministers have raised the possibility with banks supervisors of giving firms struggling with virus impact more time that the usual 90 days before their debt is classified as non-performing loans.

* CASE UPDATE: US CDC announced 472 total confirmed and presumptive cases, including repatriated cases, as of 4pm on Sunday, with the death toll rising by 8 to 19. UK cases rose to 319 (prev. 273), with the death toll rising by 2 to 5. Italy death toll rose to 463 from 366; total cases rose to 9172 from 7375. Canada reported its first death.

* CHINA TRADE: China’s trade balance for January and February saw a USD 7bln deficit, against expectations of a USD 24.6bln surplus, falling from the previous USD 47.2bln surplus. Both imports and exports declined, although the deficit was triggered by a massive 17.2% decline in exports, a deeper decline than the expected 14%, meanwhile imports declined less than expected, only falling 4% compared to an expected 15% decline. The data includes two months of data given the extended lunar new year holiday and coronavirus, the first month of data tends to see volatile data even without the extension. Analysts at UBS note that trade activity in China could return to normality by the end of this month or in early Q2.

* GEOPOLITICS: Last night, the South Korean military announced North Korea fired short range projectiles as part of ongoing drills. The missiles flew 200km and saw an altitude of 50km and Japan noted the launches were likely ballistic missiles. South Korea and Kapan were both displeased with the missile launches as it violates an agreement at lowering military animosities, although none of the launches landed within the Exclusive Economic Zone. Elsewhere in Libya, Eastern Commander Haftar reportedly agreed to signing a ceasefire deal with France’s President Macron, although noted the ceasefire would not be kept if Tripoli militias ignored it. On Iran, US President Trump’s administration will reportedly soon issue an advisory warning to anyone holding Iranian oil in violation of US sanctions and will soon issue a maritime advisory to target ships that turn off transponders to avoid sanctions.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 1 POINT 8 TICKS HIGHER AT 139.09+. The chunky bid extended on Monday amid the risk aversion and oil price collapse. The curve exhibited further bull flattening alongside weaker inflation expectations and corporate credit concerns as oil prices tumbled further towards their all-time lows, equities were also hit strongly. In the overnight session the 30-year bond was bid as much as six points, with desks noting nobody on the other side of the trade. The rally saw all yields move beneath the 1% figure for the first time in history, and participants now move to the question of when the Fed will cut again rather than if. By settlement, 2-year yield had fallen 21bps while the 30-year had fallen by 38bps to 0.840%, but above its lows of 0.702%.

* REPO: The NY Fed stepped in (somewhat) unexpectedly on Monday, raising its o/n repo operations to USD 150bln (prev. 100bln) and the Terms raised to USD 45bln (prev. 20bln); coming amid recent and expected funding pressures, and walking back on its original plan to gradually wind down its presence in the repo market. The Fed line is that it would reassess its role in the funding markets after the April 15th corporate tax date.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -7.61% at 2746, NDX -6.83% at 7948, DJI -7.79% at 23,849; SECTORS: Energy-20%, Financials -11%, Materials -9.2%, Industrials -9.2%, Technology -7.56%, Real Estate -7.15%, Communication Svs. -6.2%, Consumer Discretionary -6.2%, Utilities -5.6%, Health Care -5.2% and Consumer Staples -4.4%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: The Energy sector (XLE, XOP, FANG, APA) was generally offered heavily amid the obliteration of oil prices – although names exposed highly to nat gas fared better (COG, EQT) as the expected decline in drilling activity will be bullish for gas. Continued yield declines, risk aversion and credit concerns, particularly in the energy sector, weighed on financials (XLF, BKX), particularly regional banks (KRE), and even further those with acute loan exposure to US shale oil (BKOF, CMA, CADE). Cruise liners (CCL, RCL, NCLH) found no selling reprieve as US imposed stricter restrictions on trips. Twitter (TWTR) was one of the handful of names in the green after it announced a USD 2bln share repurchase programme while it reached a deal with Silver Lake and Elliott management, who will both get a seat on the board and funding for the share repurchase programme; there was no mention of the removal of CEO Dorsey. Tesla (TSLA) was hit hard by wider risk aversion, despite positive comments from a top shareholder doing the rounds. Apple (AAPL) moved lower with the market alongside reports of a sharp Y/Y decline in its February iPhone sales in China. Aon (AON) were hit after it agreed to purchase Willis Towers Watson (WLTW) for USD 30bln, creating an USD 80bln entity.

* FX WRAP: USD was offered and DXY printed a low of 94.632, a level not seen since September 2018, as participants flocked to safety while yields fell beneath 1% across the curve and market pricing for deeper rate cuts from the Fed continued to increase, where markets are currently pricing in over 75bps worth of easing at the upcoming March meeting. The flight to quality saw CHF and JPY firmer with EURCHF beneath the key 1.06 level while USDJPY traded as low as 101.20 before calming around the 102 figure, the appreciation in both CHF and JPY has spurred chatter of potential Central Bank intervention from both nations. XAU however failed to maintain its benefit from the haven bid although the precious metal remains around recent highs of USD 1675 heading into the final few minutes of trade after breaking above USD 1700 last night. EUR & GBP both fared better against the buck given the heavy sell off in the greenback, although the latter facing key event risk with the budget on Wednesday. Antipodes succumbed to the broader risk appetite and both sold off against the dollar, although AUDUSD came out as the clear antipodean underperformer and saw lows at 0.6323, meanwhile NZDUSD traded within 0.6158-0.6448 parameters, with much of the rebound in morning trade ahead of manufacturing sales tonight. EMFX was weaker across the board given risk appetite although USDRUB traded over 8% higher given the heavy sell off in oil prices, which also hurt MXN, meanwhile TRY a relative underperformer (USDTRY -1%) as its exposure to lower oil prices is much less given it is a net importer.

content:
USD 

The Dollar remains weak overall and only retaining gains over the petro-currencies plus EM counterparts as markets continue to factor in more aggressive Fed easing as soon as if not before the March FOMC. Indeed, despite last Tuesday’s shock 50 bp emergency rate cut, US Treasury yields have sunk further, and the curve is even flatter as all benchmark maturities trade under 1%. China’s coronavirus is still claiming more lives and spreading across the globe, but the latest issue for investors to fret about is an oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia after the latter refused to join OPEC+ in bigger crude output cuts last Friday. In response, the Kingdom has cut OSPs and announced production hikes from next month in an effort to gain market share and put pressure on Russia, while Rosneft has also signalled intentions to up output from April. WTI and Brent are well off worst levels of just over Usd27 and Usd31 per barrel respectively, but still deep underwater as the DXY clings to the 95.000 level.

JPY/EUR/CHF/NZD/GBP/AUD 

The Yen is still flying the flag for safe havens and outperforming bullion even though Usd/Jpy saw a sharp rebound from new multi-year lows closer to 101.00 after Wall Street reopened and key indices hit limit down circuit breaks (-7%) to trigger a 15 minute trade suspension. US and EU equities remain sharply lower and sentiment is very fragile, so the aforementioned bounce in Usd/Jpy to 102.50+ at one stage seemed to be fabricated on firm underlying bids, if not officially instigated. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd is holding towards the upper end of a near 1.1500-1.1285 range as the single currency benefits from the Greenback’s demise and its semi safety status rather than worrying unduly about a bleak Eurozone Sentix survey or the mounting nCoV toll in Italy, France and Germany etc. However, the Kiwi’s revival from overnight trough to peak (0.6148-0.6448) is arguably more notable ahead of NZ manufacturing sales and the Aussie is tagging along (0.6323-0.6685) on relative yield differentials and having regained some poise after a flash crash alongside its Antipodean peer. Meanwhile, the Franc and Pound are meandering into Monday’s EU ‘close’ awaiting the SNB and BoE March policy meetings, with the former also conscious of this week’s UK Budget as Cable hovers around 1.3100 and Usd/Chf near 0.9300.

CAD/NOK/SEK 

All ruffled by the latest bout of risk aversion and collapse in crude noted above, as the Loonie extends post-BOC ease declines within 1.3463-1.3759 extremes, Eur/Nok holds above 10.8000, albeit off a fresh ATH fractions shy of 11.0000 and Eur/Sek sits a few pips over 10.7500.

EM

Several regional Central Banks and regulators have been intervening to stop or curb currency depreciation caused by waves of capital flight, not to mention declines suffered on underlying commodities, including the BCB and BI. However, record lows have been recorded across the region regardless of data or more specific factors, like mixed Mexican inflation metrics and a firmer than forecast Brazilian IGP-DI price index. Nevertheless, some solace for the Try via lower oil prices and the positive fiscal impact.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: Wall Street open sparks more wild trade and whip-saw moves
content: It took a few minutes, but the first line of defence in major US equity indices was duly breached at -7% to force a time-out for 15 minutes and some respite for risk assets in general. However, core bonds extended already mega-sized safe haven gains to 179.31 (Bunds) and 139.84 (Gilts), while the 10 year US note got closer to its overnight session best (140-24), while Usd/Jpy recoiled through 101.50 to circa 101.20 before finding some underlying buying interest and rebounding around 1.5 big figures.  Back to Wall Street, the enforced limit down break appears to have restored some calm as stocks pare losses to nearer 5% and this has taken the shine off debt.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 9th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • As oil prices crash by double digits and credit spreads widen, US shale (XOP, XLE, EOG, OXY, MPC, PXD, XOM, CHK, CXO, CLT, CVX, DVN, APA) becomes an acutely vulnerable sector
  • Cruise liners (NCLH, RCL, CCL) are under further selling pressure
  • Willis Towers Watson (WLTW) (Financials/Insurance Brokers) is to combine with Aon plc (AON)

9th March 2020

As oil prices crash by double digits and credit spreads widen, US shale (XOP, XLE, EOG, OXY, MPC, PXD, XOM, CHK, CXO, CLT, CVX, DVN, APA) becomes an acutely vulnerable sector due to its already pressured margins and excessive debt loads which will likely see headwinds when Cos come to refinance. Note that oil majors in Europe have been trading with heavy losses on Monday.

Furthermore, as credit spreads widen and default risk rises, participants are growing cautious on the lenders that service energy debt, Morgan Stanley notes that mid-sized banks generally have the most exposure to energy loans, listing these names as most exposed (as a % of Q4 2019 loans) in reverse order: BOKF (18.3%), CFR (11.2%), CADE (11.0%), CMA (4.9%), CIT (4.4%), PB (3.7%), EWBC (3.6%), C (3.2%), RF (3.2%), ZION (2.9%), KEY (2.5%), BAC (1.7%), JPM (1.4%), WFC (1.4%), COF (1.4%), PNC (1.0%), USB (0.8%).

Cruise liners (NCLH, RCL, CCL) are under further selling pressure, where the latest blow lands from the Trump administration recommended Americans avoid cruise ships. Additionally, CDC have blocked several ships operated by Carnival’s Princess Cruises from leaving or docking.

SXSW has been cancelled due to COVID-19; names that were due to attend included Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX), Twitter (TWTR), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), LinkedIn (MSFT), IBM (IBM), and WarnerMedia (T).

In this week’s Barron’s publication, yield stocks were highlighted as attractive amid the drop in bond yields (MO, DOW, XOM, VLO, PRU, CMA, T, CVX, WFC, ABBV, STX, KMI, JNJ), Uber (UBER) and Lam Research (LRCX) were mentioned as names that could rebound nicely from COVID-19 selloff where there cash balances exceeds their debt.

DOW

Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) reportedly sold fewer than 500mln iPhones in China in February, compared to 1.27mln in February 2019.

Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is to be ordered by the FAA to fix electric wiring issues in the 737 MAX, according to sources cited by the WSJ.

Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) USD 10bln JEDI cloud contract deal with the Pentagon looks shaky after a US judge said Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is likely to succeed in its contract challenge lawsuit.

The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) Shanghai Disneyland is resuming some of its operations as COVID-19 infections in the region slow, but the main park remains closed.

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – The DoJ is reportedly working with AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) on whether or not it will bring an antitrust probe against Google.

Electronic Arts (EA) (Communication Services/Interactive Home Entertainment) has suspended various esports events due to COVID-19, including Apex Legends and FIFA 20.

Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has been sued by regulators in Australia on accusations of sharing user data without consent.

Tesla Inc (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is now a “better run” Co following leadership changes and regulatory battles, writes top shareholder James Anderson, head of global equities for Baillie Gifford, in the FT.

S&P 500

AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) is partnering with authorities to determine the efficacy of HIV drug in treating the coronavirus.

Citigroup Inc. (C) (Financials/Diversified Banks), as according to the FT, is severing ties with two-thirds of the FX platforms it uses as part of cost cutting measures.

PerkinElmer (PKI) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment), due to COVID-19, announced it sees Q1 results below its previous guidance of EPS at USD 0.70 and Revenue at USD 700mln.

Twitter, Inc. (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) Board authorised a USD 2bln share repurchase program, ambition in 2020 and beyond is to grow MDAU at 20% or more.

Varian Medical Systems (VAR) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment), due to COVID-19, has cut guidance, Q2 Revenue view USD 800mln-825mln (exp. 871.75mln).

Wells Fargo (WFC) (Financials/Diversified Banks) Chief Accounting Officer Richard Levy will retire after 18 years at the bank, effective April 1st.

Willis Towers Watson (WLTW) (Financials/Insurance Brokers) is to combine with Aon plc (AON), where WLTW will receive 1.08 AON share for each of their own shares; combined equity value of circa USD 80bln; under some circumstance, AON would have to pay a USD 1bln fee to Willis Towers.

OTHER

Apollo (APO) submitted a USD 20/shr, or USD 4.4bln, all-cash bid for Tegna (TGNA) (Communications Services/Media) on Friday, according to sources cited by Dealreporter; note that Gray Television (GTN) made an equal sized bid, but the deal was a mix of cash and stock.

Huawei sees smartphone shipments down around 20% this year, according to The Information, where suppliers include Micron Technology (MU) and Western Digital (WDC).

Uber Inc (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail) and Lyft (LYFT) said they will compensate drivers who are diagnosed with COVID-19, or those placed in quarantine.

subject: China says coronavirus situation remains complex but will firmly prevent the rebound of the epidemic
Russia's Rosneft is poised to increase production from April while are also said to be prepared for any oil price scenarios
analysis_details:
• Sources over the weekend noted that Saudi Arabia will be boosting its output to above 10mln BPD from this month’s 9.7mln BPD as a response to the collapse of the OPEC+ alliance with Russia. Saudi is said to have told market participants that it could raise output to as much as 12mln BPD, although sources stated that the initial increase is likely to total between 10-11mln BPD in April, with the final figure contingent on refiners’ response to price cuts.
  • Furthermore, the Kingdom slashed its official pricing for crude, with oil behemoth Aramco cutting its Asia prices for Arab Light crude and Medium crude by USD 6/bbl each, to discounts of USD 3.10/bbl and USD 4.05/bbl below the Middle East benchmark respectively. In a challenge to Russia, the company made the largest cut to northwest Europe of some USD 8/bbl in most grades – Russia sells a bulk of its Urals crude in the same region. Finally, Arab Light sales to Europe will be at a USD 10.25/bbl discount to Brent – levels not seen since at least May 2002.
  • Note, after OPEC+ failed to reach an agreement Russia's energy minister Novak stated from April 1st, they will not be bound to any restrictions, although at the time Novak stated it had no plans of increasing output, but this has seemingly changed given weekend events.

subject: Indian Government are reportedly in discussion over re-jigging exercise duty to take advantage of lower oil prices, ET citing sources in the Finance Ministry
Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • US equity futures hit limit down as the sell-off resumed driven by the virus, energy and safe-haven flows
  • WTI and Brent front month futures traded with losses over USD 10/bbl after Saudi announced supply above 10.0mln BPD from April and slashed OSP’s
  • Yields have dropped to fresh all-time lows which has seen the US curve entirely below 1.0% for the first time
  • DXY is subdued given JPY outperformance (USD/JPY low 101.58) while commodity-linked currencies are feeling the pinch
  • South Korea military noted that North Korea fired 3 unidentified projectiles off the east coast which was presumed to be multiple types of short-range projectiles
  • Note, US clocks have changed to Summer Time as such the London – New York time gap is 4-hours until March 29th
  • Looking ahead highlights include Canadian Housing Starts, US Employment Trends

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 40 additional cases of coronavirus and 22 additional deaths on March 8th vs. Prev. 44 additional cases and 27 additional deaths on March 7th to bring the total number of cases in China to 80735 and death toll at 3119. (Newswires)

South Korea coronavirus cases rose by 344 to a total of 7478 and it had 1 additional death to raise the death toll to 51. (Newswires)

Japan's MOF's Takeuchi says that the worry about the US economy impact from the coronavirus is a major factor behind the nervous moves seen in markets; will respond to excess volatility as is appropriate. Will watch market moves with a greater sense of urgency. (Newswires)

BoJ have purchased JPY 101.4bln of ETF's today, which is the 3rd time this month. (Newswires)

Italy’s COVID-19 confirmed cases rose to 7375 from Prev. 5883 and the total death toll in the country rose by 136 to a total 366, while the country has placed up to 16mln people under quarantine in which anyone living in Lombardy as well as 14 central and northern provinces, would need special permission to travel. (Newswires)

France’s coronavirus cases increased by 117 to a total of 1126 and the death toll rose by 3 to a total of 19, while it has banned all gatherings involving over 1000 people. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire says the ECB has room for manoeuvre on the coronavirus; European Finance Ministers need to come to an economic stimulus plan for the coronavirus, which needs to contain both budgetary and fiscal measures. ECB has margin and can support banks that lend, also calls on Europe to work on fiscal stimulus plan (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy says the slowdown due to the coronavirus is potentially severe but is temporary. (Newswires)

Italy's Deputy Economy Minister says the government and Bank of Italy are looking into a guarantee scheme, to support banks offering moratorium to households and Co's following the virus outbreak; considering extending tax moratorium as well. (Newswires)

New York Mayor De Blasio said the city could have 100 coronavirus cases within 2 or 3 weeks and there could be hundreds of positive cases in the city at some point. (Newswires)

US President Trump aides are drafting economic measures to combat the virus including expanding paid sick leave although it has not been presented to President Trump yet. (Newswires)

US National Institute of Allergy & Infectious Disease Head Fauci said he is concerned over community spread, and has cautioned the increasing number of cases is making determining how the virus is contracted harder; adding further concern to large events. (FT)

German Chancellor Merkel’s government has loosened rules for short-term work compensation, making it easier for Co.’s impacted by coronavirus to apply for aid. Government is set to invest a further EUR 12.1bln per annum between 2021 and 2024. (Newswires)

In related news, the State Department issued a statement related to the increased risk of COVID-19 infection on a cruise ship environment in which it stated that older adults and travellers with underlying health issues should avoid situations that put them at increased risk for more severe disease. This entails avoiding crowded places, avoiding non-essential travel such as long plane trips, and especially avoiding embarking on cruise ships. (Washington Post/Newswires)

China's Civil Aviation Authority announce measures to help airlines amidst the virus; include, reducing airport/air control fees and postponing a flight implementation plan. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets resumed their slump and US equity futures also suffered heavy losses in which the E-mini S&P hit limit down and DJIA futures pointed to another decline of over-1000 points, as oil prices slipped by around 30% after Saudi Arabia kicked off an oil price war. The kingdom announced plans to raise its output to over 10mln bpd beginning next month and it cut the OSP for all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl following last week’s breakdown of the OPEC+ output deal in which Russia rejected the proposal for additional cuts. ASX 200 (-7.3%) posted its largest intraday loss in more than 11 years amid a collapse across the energy sector although gold miners bucked the trend due to the flight to safety, while Nikkei 225 (-5.1%) gapped below 20K and continued to tumble against the backdrop of the detrimental currency flows and following the miss on Q4 GDP which further pointed to the likelihood of a looming recession. Hang Seng (-4.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-3.0%) conformed to the sell off as blue-chip energy names were pummelled and after continued PBoC liquidity inaction, while the latest trade data from China over the weekend showed a surprise Trade Deficit and a larger than expected contraction in Exports. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the bloodbath in stocks and as it tracked the advances in T-notes which surged nearly 2 points as US 10yr and 30yr yields delved into unprecedented levels, while the BoJ were also present in the market today for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs. 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9260 vs. Exp. 6.9228 (Prev. 6.9337)

Chinese Trade Balance YTD (USD)(Feb) -7.09B vs. Exp. 24.6B (Prev. 47.21B) (Newswires)

Chinese Exports YTD (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -17.2% vs. Exp. -14.0% (Prev. 7.9%)

Chinese Imports YTD (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -4.0% vs. Exp. -15.0% (Prev. 16.5%)

Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Q/Q -1.8% vs. Exp. -1.7% (Prev. -1.6%)

Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Y/Y -7.1% vs. Exp. -6.6% (Prev. -6.3%)

US

US President Trump replaced Mick Mulvaney with Rep. Mark Meadows as White House Chief of Staff. (Newswires)

US Administration is pushing for additional trade restrictions via the implementation of national security concerns, contradicting Trump's position last-month that he was eager for US Co's to sell freely to China, WSJ. (WSJ)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak has promised “targeted” measures to assist businesses and workers “get through to the other side” of an economic downturn and warned of a shock that could be caused by a coronavirus epidemic, while he stated this week’s Budget would include plans to give firms additional time to pay tax if staff were unable to work and shoppers stopped spending money in the normal way. (Telegraph) UK Chancellor Sunak is reportedly under pressure from industry groups to not fund coronavirus measures with tax hikes on businesses. (Guardian) This comes ahead of the UK budget unveiling this Wednesday

UK PM Johnson will be chairing an emergency Cobra meeting at 11:00GMT to decide whether to bring in measures to delay the spread of coronavirus in the UK. The meeting is expected to mull whether “social distancing” measures should be introduced. (BBC) This comes amid weekend developments which saw the confirmed number of cases in the UK rising to 278 on Sunday vs. 209 on Saturday, the largest increase so far. 

Fitch affirmed European Stability Mechanism at AAA, while it affirmed Luxembourg at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Ukraine at B; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European opened substantially into negative territory this morning (Stoxx 50 -6.6%) as sentiment remains subdued on the coronavirus, but with the added development of a crude-war between Saudi Arabia and Russia after the OPEC+ bust-up on Friday (Full details available in the commodity section below). It’s worth noting that sentiment has begun to recuperate somewhat, with US equity futures trading briefly above the limit down positions that were hit overnight (Limit Down Details). Given the commitments from Saudi to increase production to over 10.0mln BPD as of next month and they have cut the official selling price for all destinations by around USD 7/bbl, crude prices are as such lower by over USD 10/bbl and the energy sector has similarly recoiled (Stoxx Oil & Gas -13%). The Oil & Gas Sector accounts for 5.5% of the Stoxx 500 itself, and the largest weightings withing the sector are Total at 29.4%, BP with 15.5% and Shell contributing 14.5%; in terms of price performance, they are currently down by 13.3%, 15.7% and 16.7% respectively. Additionally, the overall downside is exacerbated by the FTQ seen overnight which has sent the global yield complex to record lows for most core parties. For instance, the entirety of the US yield curve is below 1% for the first time and the German 10yr low thus far resides at -0.86%. The Stoxx banking sector is the sector with the 3rd largest weighting in the Stoxx 600 representing 9.4% and is currently 7.3% down on the day. Elsewhere, sectors are all firmly in the red as is every open component in the Stoxx 600 itself; note, a number of Co’s failed, at least initially, to open. Looking ahead, focus turns to how markets react to the US’ entrance, particularly whether this exacerbates the sell-off; as well as for any indicative signs from any particular Co’s in the Energy/Banking sector regarding profit warnings, guidance changes or other telling comments.

Circuit Breakers:

·       S&P 500: During non-US trading hours (Futures) – Hard upside or downside limit of 5% from 1800EST/2200GMT to 0930EST/1330GMT.

o    Midpoint of the limit is based on the futures fixing price

o    Width of limit is based on index value at 1600EST/2000GMT

 

·       S&P 500: During US trading hours (Cash)

o    7% fall to 2764.30 before 15:25EST/19:25GMT will prompt a 15-minute pause.

o    13% drop before said time to 2585.96 will introduce another 15-minute pause.

o    A fall of 20% within the time will shut the markets; only the 20% rule applies to the final 35 minutes of trading.

 

·       NASDAQ: Nasdaq futures will stop falling if the contract reaches 8093.25.

·       DOW JONES: DJ futures will stop falling if the contract trades below 24534

Apple (AAPL) - 5G iPhone release may be pushed-back to October, which would be a delay of 1-month, due to the coronavirus, according to Global Times Business Source. (Newswires)

FX

NOK/SEK/RUB/CAD/AUD/NZD - Risk sentiment has been roiled by Saudi Arabia’s decision to increase output and slash the cost of crude in response to the breakdown of OPEC+ talks last week when Russia refused to back a deeper cut in production, as prices tumble and compound fears over the economic fallout from China’s nCoV. Eur/Nok has hit highs just shy of 11.0000 and Eur/Sek topped 10.7500, while Usd/Rub peered over 75.0000 before WTI and Brent nursed some losses from just above Usd27 and Usd31 per barrel respectively. Meanwhile, Usd/Cad catapulted to 1.3750+ at one stage overnight and the Antipodean Dollars saw flash crashes that dragged Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd down to circa 0.6320 and 0.6030, but the Loonie, Aussie and Kiwi have all clawed back some lost ground as their US peer succumbs to pressure from sliding Treasury yields and more pronounced bull-flattening along the curve, not to mention heavy depreciation vs safer havens.

JPY/EUR/CHF/GBP - In stark contrast to all the above, Usd/Jpy has been trading largely in lock-step with oil with added impetus from risk-off flows/positioning between wide 104.58-101.58 parameters and the Yen retains a strong underlying bid unlike GOLD that has faded from a few bucks over Usd1700/oz at best on profit taking and long liquidation. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd hit resistance just ahead of 1.1500 and Usd/Chf based a few pips under 0.9200 as Eur/Chf bottomed around 1.0510 in advance of Swiss jobs data and sight deposits showing another rise in bank balances. Similarly, Cable waned after touching 1.3200 with Sterling still subject to hard Brexit jitters alongside the coronavirus and crude capitulation that pose growth and financial stability threats. However, the DXY remains vulnerable itself within a 95.694-94.719 range and not far from a key technical level at worst (94.080 representing a 50% retracement from ytd peak).

EM - Severe underperformance in extreme or bordering on unprecedented levels of aversion, especially through the cross-over from Asia-Pacific to European time zones has ravaged regional currencies, though the Lira has rebounded more than most on the vastly cheaper oil price as a net importer and the Yuan is holding firmly above 7.0000 after another decline in the Usd/Cny fix.

FIXED

It may be somewhat premature or even remiss to contend that debt futures/cash yields have marked out their highs/lows for now, but as equites bounce from subterranean levels and the drilling in oil abates there is some degree of calm after the earlier storm. Hence, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries are ‘only’ 1-2 points ahead vs over 2 to nearly 3 big figures above parity when thinner liquidity and catch up trade exacerbated the scramble for safe-haven assets. However, it remains to be seen what happens when US participants return to the fray and an hour earlier given that clocks went forward by 60 minutes before Europe at the end of March. Ahead, some NA data due, but it’s all about risk sentiment surrounding COVID-19 and now the next manoeuvres in crude markets.

GEOPOLITICS

South Korea military noted that North Korea fired 3 unidentified projectiles off the east coast which was presumed to be multiple types of short-range projectiles, while it added this was part of ongoing firing drills and that the projectiles flew 200KM and reached 50KM in altitude. (Newswires)

Saudi Crown Prince MBS has accused two of Saudi’s most Senior Royals of treason following accusations of organising a coup against the Crown Prince; with the two royals in question regarded as among the few individuals in the way of MBS’ ascension (Guardian)

COMMODITIES

A frantic session for commodities to say the least after sources over the weekend noted that Saudi Arabia will be boosting its output to above 10mln BPD from this month’s 9.7mln BPD as a response to the collapse of its OPEC+ alliance with Russia. Saudi is also said to have told market participants that it could raise output to as much as 12mln BPD, although sources stated that the initial increase is likely to total between 10-11mln BPD in April, with the final figure contingent on refiners’ response to price cuts. Furthermore, the Kingdom slashed its official pricing for crude, with oil giant Aramco cutting its Asia prices for Arab Light crude and Medium crude by USD 6/bbl each, to discounts of USD 3.10/bbl and USD 4.05/bbl below the Middle East benchmark respectively. In a challenge to Russia, the company made the largest cut to northwest Europe of some USD 8/bbl in most grades – Russia sells a bulk of its Urals crude in the same region. Arab Light sales to Europe will be at a USD 10.25/bbl discount to Brent – levels not seen since at least May 2002. As a result of the anticipated rising production and slash in OSPs – expected to flood the market with barrels – WTI and Brent futures sank 27% and 30% respectively, with the former paused for a few minutes following its aggressive >7% move. WTI Apr’20 briefly slipped below USD 28/bbl vs. Friday’s USD 41.50/bbl close, while Brent May 20 dipping south of USD 32/bbl vs. Friday’s USD 45.50/close – with the spread also narrowing to ~USD 3.80/bbl vs. ~4/bbl on Friday. The Kingdom hopes the slump in oil prices and the expected diminishing in Russia’s market shares will prompt Moscow back to the negotiating table and force its hand to cut output. Desks note that although this may prove effective in the short-term, it is in less certain what the longer-term impact will be. The front-month energy contracts have, as European players entered the markets, pared some losses with WTI Apr’20 now back to ~USD 32.50/bbl, with the 29th Jan 2016 low at USD 26.19/bbl, whilst the Brent May contract reclaimed a USD 36/bbl status. Away from the OPEC debacle, IEA cut 2020 world oil demand forecasts by almost 1mln BPD, due to the coronavirus; envisage the first contraction since 2009, noting that Demand could drop by 730k BPD, in an extreme event where Gov't fails to contain the virus. Price action to the report was muted given the omission of a scenario that incorporates the weekend Saudi/Russian news. Elsewhere, spot gold failed to hold onto impetus from the global stock rout after prices briefly surpassed USD 1700/oz to the upside to prices last seen in December 2012. The yellow metal then waned off highs and into negative territory – potentially on profit-taking and as investors pump money into government debts in search of safe-haven assets. Meanwhile, copper conformed to the overall risk tone and gapped lower at the open, losing the USD 2.5/lb handle to a current low of USD 2.4675/lb.

Saudi Arabia launched an oil price war to punish Russia following the breakdown of the oil deal in which the kingdom announced it will offer deep discounts by lowering OSP to all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl, while it is to raise crude output to more than 10mln bpd next month. (Newswires/FT)

IEA Monthly Report: cut 2020 world oil demand forecasts by almost 1mln BPD, due to the coronavirus; envisage the first contraction since 2009. (Newswires)

-        Q1 oil demand to drop by 2.49mln BPD vs. Prev.

-        Q2 oil demand to drop by 40k BPD, then rising to 1.35mln BPD in Q3 and by 800k BPD in Q4

-        Forecast oil demand at 99.9mln BPD in 2020, -90k vs. 2019

-        Demand could drop by 730k BPD, in a extreme event where Gov't fails to contain the virus

Calls on OPEC crude is anticipated to increase by 2mln BPD to 30.6mln in 2025. World oil production capacity is set to increase by 5.9mln BPD by 2025, which will driven by Non-OPEC growth

IEA's Chief Birol says prices below USD 25/bbl would stop new US shale developments, sees the potential for a oil overhand of 3.5mln BPD in Q1 due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

At least 4 Asian refineries reportedly aim to maximise purchases for April following Saudi Arabia's price cuts and Goldman Sachs Commodities Research lowered its Brent crude price forecasts to USD 30/bbl for Q2 and Q3. (Newswires)

FX Morning Colour: crude awakening for currency markets as oil prices plummet
content:
NOK/SEK/RUB/CAD/AUD/NZD

Risk sentiment has been roiled by Saudi Arabia’s decision to increase output and slash the cost of crude in response to the breakdown of OPEC+ talks last week when Russia refused to back a deeper cut in production, as prices tumble and compound fears over the economic fallout from China’s nCoV. Eur/Nok has hit highs just shy of 11.0000 and Eur/Sek topped 10.7500, while Usd/Rub peered over 75.0000 before WTI and Brent nursed some losses from just above Usd27 and Usd31 per barrel respectively. Meanwhile, Usd/Cad catapulted to 1.3750+ at one stage overnight and the Antipodean Dollars saw flash crashes that dragged Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd down to circa 0.6320 and 0.6030, but the Loonie, Aussie and Kiwi have all clawed back some lost ground as their US peer succumbs to pressure from sliding Treasury yields and more pronounced bull-flattening along the curve, not to mention heavy depreciation vs safer havens.

JPY/EUR/CHF/GBP

In stark contrast to all the above, Usd/Jpy has been trading largely in lock-step with oil with added impetus from risk-off flows/positioning between wide 104.58-101.58 parameters and the Yen retains a strong underlying bid unlike GOLD that has faded from a few bucks over Usd1700/oz at best on profit taking and long liquidation. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd hit resistance just ahead of 1.1500 and Usd/Chf based a few pips under 0.9200 as Eur/Chf bottomed around 1.0510 in advance of Swiss jobs data and sight deposits showing another rise in bank balances. Similarly, Cable waned after touching 1.3200 with Sterling still subject to hard Brexit jitters alongside the coronavirus and crude capitulation that pose growth and financial stability threats. However, the DXY remains vulnerable itself within a 95.694-94.719 range and not far from a key technical level at worst (94.080 representing a 50% retracement from ytd peak).

EM

Severe underperformance in extreme or bordering on unprecedented levels of aversion, especially through the cross-over from Asia-Pacific to European time zones has ravaged regional currencies, though the Lira has rebounded more than most on the vastly cheaper oil price as a net importer and the Yuan is holding firmly above 7.0000 after another decline in the Usd/Cny fix.

ANALYSIS: SAUDI PLAYS CHICKEN WITH MOSCOW, OIL PRICES COLLAPSE
content:
*LONG STORY SHORT:

Sources over the weekend noted that Saudi Arabia will be boosting its output to above 10mln BPD from this month’s 9.7mln BPD as a response to the collapse of the OPEC+ alliance with Russia. Saudi is said to have told market participants that it could raise output to as much as 12mln BPD, although sources stated that the initial increase is likely to total between 10-11mln BPD in April, with the final figure contingent on refiners’ response to price cuts.

Furthermore, the Kingdom slashed its official pricing for crude, with oil behemoth Aramco cutting its Asia prices for Arab Light crude and Medium crude by USD 6/bbl each, to discounts of USD 3.10/bbl and USD 4.05/bbl below the Middle East benchmark respectively. In a challenge to Russia, the company made the largest cut to northwest Europe of some USD 8/bbl in most grades – Russia sells a bulk of its Urals crude in the same region. Finally, Arab Light sales to Europe will be at a USD 10.25/bbl discount to Brent – levels not seen since at least May 2002.

*TENSIONS BUILDUP:

The move by Saudi follows the collapse in ties with Russia after Moscow refused to yield to Saudi’s 1.5mln BPD output curb proposal but instead vied to extend the current cuts. The Kingdom hopes the slump in oil prices and the expected diminishing in Russia’s market shares will prompt Moscow back to the negotiating table and force its hand to cut output. Desks note that although this may prove effective in the short-term, it is in less certain what the longer-term impact will be.

*PRICE ACTION:

As a result of the anticipated rising production and slash in OSPs – expected to flood the market with barrels – WTI and Brent futures sank 27% and 30% respectively, with the former paused for a few minutes following its aggressive >7% move. WTI Apr’20 briefly slipped below USD 28/bbl vs. Friday’s USD 41.50/bbl close, while Brent May 20 dipping south of USD 32/bbl vs. Friday’s USD 45.50/close – with the spread also narrowing to ~USD 3.80/bbl vs. ~4/bbl on Friday.

Unsurprisingly, oil names bore the brunt of the slump in overnight trade – with Saudi Aramco shares sinking 10% (market cap now below USD 1.5tln), whilst Chinese and Australian producers also plumbed the depths, a move likely to reverberate in European and US oil stocks.

*SGH MACRO VIEW:

Understand that for any new agreement, the Saudis will now demand the Russians make real rather than token cuts in output and at the beginning rather than the end of the agreement period, and that seems unlikely to be forthcoming.

*HOUSE CALL TWEAKS:

In light of the latest developments, ING has slashed their Brent forecasts and now expect prices to average USD 33/bbl in Q2 (Prev. USD 56/bbl), with H2 prices expected to average ~USD 43/bbl (forecasts included below).

In terms of US supply, analysts at Berenberg expect the drop in WTI to trigger sharp declines in rig counts and production outlooks from Shale companies in the coming months. “If this is not enough to rebalance the market in the short term, then oil prices could approach cash cost levels to force shut-ins of existing wells to reduce production immediately, and historically that has required oil prices below USD30/bbl Brent”, the analysts said.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

9th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets resumed their slump and US equity futures also suffered heavy losses in which the E-mini S&P hit limit down and DJIA futures pointed to another decline of over-1000 points, as oil prices slipped by around 30% after Saudi Arabia kicked off an oil price war. The kingdom announced plans to raise its output to over 10mln bpd beginning next month and it cut the OSP for all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl following last week’s breakdown of the OPEC+ output deal in which Russia rejected the proposal for additional cuts. ASX 200 (-7.3%) posted its largest intraday loss in more than 11 years amid a collapse across the energy sector although gold miners bucked the trend due to the flight to safety, while Nikkei 225 (-5.4%) gapped below 20K and continued to tumble against the backdrop of the detrimental currency flows and following the miss on Q4 GDP which further pointed to the likelihood of a looming recession. Hang Seng (-3.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) conformed to the sell off as blue-chip energy names were pummelled and after continued PBoC liquidity inaction, while the latest trade data from China over the weekend showed a surprise Trade Deficit and a larger than expected contraction in Exports. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the bloodbath in stocks and as it tracked the advances in T-notes which surged nearly 2 points as US 10yr and 30yr yields delved into unprecedented levels, while the BoJ were also present in the market today for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 9th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·       Asian equity markets resumed their slump and US equity futures also suffered heavy losses in which the E-mini S&P hit limit down

·       Saudi Arabia launched an oil price war to punish Russia following the breakdown of the oil deal in which the Kingdom announced it will offer deep discounts by lowering OSP to all destinations

·       WTI crude futures suffering losses of more than 31% to below USD 29/bbl and Brent crude also fell off a cliff to a floor of around USD 32.00/bbl.

·       DXY briefly slipped below 95.00 amid the decline in yields in which the 10yr fell to a fresh record low beneath 0.5% and the 30yr yield breached 1.0% for the first time ever

·       South Korea military noted that North Korea fired 3 unidentified projectiles off the east coast which was presumed to be multiple types of short-range projectiles

·       Italy has placed up to 16mln people under quarantine in which anyone living in Lombardy as well as 14 central and northern provinces would need special permission to travel

·       Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Output, Trade, IEA Monthly Report, Eurozone Sentix

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

Mainland China reported 40 additional cases of coronavirus and 22 additional deaths on March 8th vs. Prev. 44 additional cases and 27 additional deaths on March 7th to bring the total number of cases in China to 80735 and death toll at 3119. (Newswires)

South Korea coronavirus cases rose by 248 to a total of 7382 and it had 1 additional death to raise the death toll to 51. (Newswires)

Italy’s COVID-19 confirmed cases rose to 7375 from Prev. 5883 and the total death toll in the country rose by 136 to a total 366, while the country has placed up to 16mln people under quarantine in which anyone living in Lombardy as well as 14 central and northern provinces, would need special permission to travel. (Newswires)

France’s coronavirus cases increased by 117 to a total of 1126 and the death toll rose by 3 to a total of 19, while it has banned all gatherings involving over 1000 people. (Newswires)

New York Mayor De Blasio said the city could have 100 coronavirus cases within 2 or 3 weeks and there could be hundreds of positive cases in the city at some point. (Newswires)

US President Trump aides are drafting economic measures to combat the virus including expanding paid sick leave although it has not been presented to President Trump yet. (Newswires)

US National Institute of Allergy & Infectious Disease Head Fauci said he is concerned over community spread, and has cautioned the increasing number of cases is making determining how the virus is contracted harder; adding further concern to large events. (FT)

German Chancellor Merkel’s government has loosened rules for short-term work compensation, making it easier for Co.’s impacted by coronavirus to apply for aid. Government is set to invest a further EUR 12.1bln per annum between 2021 and 2024. (Newswires)

US granted exclusions from import tariffs for more than 100 medical items imported from China, including face masks, examination gloves and sanitizing wipes and the White House is reportedly looking at tax deferral for airline, travel, and cruise industries impacted by coronavirus. In related news, the State Department issued a statement related to the increased risk of COVID-19 infection on a cruise ship environment in which it stated that older adults and travellers with underlying health issues should avoid situations that put them at increased risk for more severe disease. This entails avoiding crowded places, avoiding non-essential travel such as long plane trips, and especially avoiding embarking on cruise ships. (WSJ/Washington Post/Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets resumed their slump and US equity futures also suffered heavy losses in which the E-mini S&P hit limit down and DJIA futures pointed to another decline of over-1000 points, as oil prices slipped by around 30% after Saudi Arabia kicked off an oil price war. The kingdom announced plans to raise its output to over 10mln bpd beginning next month and it cut the OSP for all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl following last week’s breakdown of the OPEC+ output deal in which Russia rejected the proposal for additional cuts. ASX 200 (-7.3%) posted its largest intraday loss in more than 11 years amid a collapse across the energy sector although gold miners bucked the trend due to the flight to safety, while Nikkei 225 (-5.4%) gapped below 20K and continued to tumble against the backdrop of the detrimental currency flows and following the miss on Q4 GDP which further pointed to the likelihood of a looming recession. Hang Seng (-3.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) conformed to the sell off as blue-chip energy names were pummelled and after continued PBoC liquidity inaction, while the latest trade data from China over the weekend showed a surprise Trade Deficit and a larger than expected contraction in Exports. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the bloodbath in stocks and as it tracked the advances in T-notes which surged nearly 2 points as US 10yr and 30yr yields delved into unprecedented levels, while the BoJ were also present in the market today for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs. 

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9260 vs. Exp. 6.9228 (Prev. 6.9337)

 

Chinese Trade Balance YTD (USD)(Feb) -7.09B vs. Exp. 24.6B (Prev. 47.21B) (Newswires)

Chinese Exports YTD (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -17.2% vs. Exp. -14.0% (Prev. 7.9%)

Chinese Imports YTD (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -4.0% vs. Exp. -15.0% (Prev. 16.5%)

 

Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Q/Q -1.8% vs. Exp. -1.7% (Prev. -1.6%)

Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Y/Y -7.1% vs. Exp. -6.6% (Prev. -6.3%)

 

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak has promised “targeted” measures to assist businesses and workers “get through to the other side” of an economic downturn and warned of a shock that could be caused by a coronavirus epidemic, while he stated this week’s Budget would include plans to give firms additional time to pay tax if staff were unable to work and shoppers stopped spending money in the normal way. (Telegraph) UK Chancellor Sunak is reportedly under pressure from industry groups to not fund coronavirus measures with tax hikes on businesses. (Guardian) This comes ahead of the UK budget unveiling this Wednesday

UK PM Johnson will be chairing an emergency Cobra meeting later today to decide whether to bring in measures to delay the spread of coronavirus in the UK. The meeting is expected to mull whether “social distancing” measures should be introduced. (BBC) This comes amid weekend developments which saw the confirmed number of cases in the UK rising to 278 on Sunday vs. 209 on Saturday, the largest increase so far. 

Fitch affirmed European Stability Mechanism at AAA, while it affirmed Luxembourg at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Ukraine at B; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets were tumultuous in which the DXY briefly slipped below the 95.00 level with pressure seen amid the decline in yields in which the 10yr yield fell to a fresh record low beneath 0.5% and the 30yr yield breached under 1.0% for the first time ever. In addition, Fed Fund Rate futures priced in around 92% probability of another 75 bps cut by the Fed this month, while the greenback’s woes benefitted its transatlantic counterparts in which EUR/USD briefly approached 1.1500 where it was met with heavy resistance and GBP/USD momentarily eyed a reclaim of the 1.3100 handle. The spooked sentiment and sell-off in crude reverberated across currencies resulting to a bout of panic selling in USD/JPY which briefly fell below 102.00 to levels last seen in 2016, while commodity linked currencies AUD, CAD and NZD were also pressured resulting to a mini flash crash in which AUD/USD and NZD/USD gave up around 2 points in less than a minute to trade with losses of more than 4.5% before reversing the majority of the nose dive. EM currencies suffered the fallout from the rout especially MXN and RUB which were the underperformers with losses of more than 5% and 6% respectively, as they took a double whammy from the hot money outflows and their energy exposure. 

COMMODITIES

Oil prices declined heavily and were on track for their biggest decline on record after Saudi began an oil price war with the announcement of price cuts and to raise its output to over 10mln bpd, which was seen as a scorched earth retaliation to the collapsed OPEC+ agreement after Russia rejected additional output cuts. This pressured oil prices heavily with WTI crude futures suffering losses of more than 31% to below USD 29/bbl and Brent crude also fell off a cliff to a floor of around USD 32.00/bbl. Elsewhere, gold was initially underpinned by flight to safety but then wiped out all the gains after hitting resistance at the USD 1700/oz level, while copper fell at the open in tandem with risk appetite before consolidating just beneath USD 2.50/lb and with LME copper printing its lowest since May 2017.

Saudi Arabia launched an oil price war to punish Russia following the breakdown of the oil deal in which the kingdom announced it will offer deep discounts by lowering OSP to all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl, while it is to raise crude output to more than 10mln bpd next month. (Newswires/FT)

At least 4 Asian refineries reportedly aim to maximise purchases for April following Saudi Arabia's price cuts and Goldman Sachs Commodities Research lowered its Brent crude price forecasts to USD 30/bbl for Q2 and Q3. (Newswires)

Baker Hughes US Rig Count (6th March): Oil +4 at 682, nat gas -1 at 109 and total +3 at 793. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

South Korea military noted that North Korea fired 3 unidentified projectiles off the east coast which was presumed to be multiple types of short-range projectiles, while it added this was part of ongoing firing drills and that the projectiles flew 200KM and reached 50KM in altitude. (Newswires)

 

Saudi Crown Prince MBS has accused two of Saudi’s most Senior Royals of treason following accusations of organising a coup against the Crown Prince; with the two royals in question regarding as the few individuals in the way of MBS’ ascension (Guardian)

 

US 

The TPLEX bull-flattened intensely on Friday, bringing the 30-year yield to unseen territory – where it currently lies within the Fed’s target range, while the rest of the curve sits beneath it. No one “reason” supported the price movement, but desks note ongoing haven flows amid the virus from real money buyers, flows from convexity buyers, and chunky short-covering from leveraged accounts, in addition to an unwinding of market hedges. Furthermore, investors are likely piling into duration ahead of the weekend, where participants again dare expose themselves to risk in the face of COVID-19 and an expected rise in US cases. The sharp decline in energy prices served as the cherry on the cake as investors begin pricing in lower inflation expectations and question the stability of the global economy, increasing the allure of the sovereign bond market. By settlement, yields had fallen 9bps in the 2-year yield, 19.5bps in the 10-year yield and a jaw-dropping 33bps in the 30-year yield. US T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point & 9 ticks higher at 138-01+.

Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) said he thinks the world of very low neutral rates is likely to stay with us. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (Non-Voter, Hawk) said the Fed should be allowed to purchase a broader range of securities and assets if the COVID-19 outbreak forces the Fed to launch a new round of asset purchases. (Newswires)

Fed's George (Non-Voter, Hawk) said the longer-run costs of balance sheet policies have not been fully taken into account and large scale asset purchases have contributed to elevated asset valuations, while she added the Fed's large balance sheet could tempt fiscal authorities to view the Fed as a funding source for its spending programmes. (Newswires)

US President Trump replaced Mick Mulvaney with Rep. Mark Meadows as White House Chief of Staff. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asian markets were in panic mode as oil prices dropped around 30% after Saudi kicked off an oil price war
content: Asian equity markets resumed their slump and US equity futures also suffered heavy losses in which the Emini S&P hit limit down and DJIA futures pointed to another decline of over-1000 points, as oil prices slipped by around 30% after Saudi Arabia kicked off an oil price war. The kingdom announced plans to raise its output to over 10mln bpd beginning next month and it cut the OSP for all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl following last week’s breakdown of the OPEC+ output deal in which Russia rejected the proposal for additional cuts. ASX 200 (-7.3%) posted its largest intraday loss in more than 11 years amid a collapse across the energy sector although gold miners bucked the trend due to the flight to safety, while Nikkei 225 (-5.4%) gapped below 20K and continued to tumble against the backdrop of the detrimental currency flows and following the miss on Q4 GDP which further pointed to the likelihood of a looming recession. Hang Seng (-3.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) conformed to the sell off as blue-chip energy names were pummelled and after continued PBoC liquidity inaction, while the latest trade data from China over the weekend showed a surprise Trade Deficit and a larger than expected contraction in Exports. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the bloodbath in stocks and as it tracked the advances in T-notes which surged nearly 2 points as US 10yr and 30yr yields delved into unprecedented levels, while the BoJ were also present in the market today for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asian markets are in panic mode as oil prices dropped by as much as 30% after Saudi kicked off an oil price war
content:
Asian equity markets resume their slump and US equity futures also suffer heavy losses in which S&P 500 futures hit limit down and with DJIA futures pointing to another slide of over 1000 points, as oil prices slipped by as much as 30% after Saudi Arabia kicked off an oil price war. The kingdom announced plans to raise its output to over 10mln bpd beginning next month and it cut the OSP for all destinations by USD 6-8/bbl following last week’s breakdown of the OPEC+ output deal after Russia rejected the proposal for additional cuts. ASX 200 (-5.7%) slipped over 6% to notch its largest intraday loss in more than 11 years amid a collapse across the energy sector although gold miners buck the trend due to the flight to safety, while Nikkei 225 (-5.8%) gapped below 20K and continued to tumble against the backdrop of the detrimental currency flows and following the miss on Q4 GDP which further points to the likelihood of a looming recession. Hang Seng (-4.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) conform to the sell off as blue-chip energy names are pummelled and after continued PBoC liquidity inaction, while the latest trade data from China over the weekend showed a surprise Trade Deficit and a larger than expected contraction in Exports.

FX markets are tumultuous in which the DXY slipped below the 95.00 level despite last week’s better than expected US NFP jobs data and lower Unemployment Rate, with pressure seen amid the decline in yields in which the 10yr yield fell to a fresh record low beneath 0.5% and the 30yr yield breached under 1.0% for the first time ever. In addition, Fed Fund Rate futures price in 98.5% probability of another 50bps cut by the Fed this month, while the greenback’s woes benefitted its transatlantic counterparts in which EUR/USD briefly approached 1.1500 where it was met with heavy resistance and GBP/USD momentarily eyed a reclaim of the 1.3100 handle. The spooked sentiment and sell-off in crude also reverberated across currencies resulting to a bout of panic selling in USD/JPY which briefly fell below 102.00 to levels last seen in 2016, while commodity linked currencies AUD, CAD and NZD were also pressured resulting to a mini flash crash in which AUD/USD and NZD/USD gave up around 2 points in less than a minute to trade with losses of more than 4.5% before reversing the majority of the nose dive.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher amid the bloodbath in stocks and as it tracks the gains in T-notes which have surged nearly 2 points as US 10yr and 30yr yields slip to unprecedented levels, while the BoJ are also present in the market today for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs.
